Rentrak bobbed above that entry point recently, but volume was below average. Rentrak has seen revenue decline in the home video content side of its business. In the latest 10-Q report,…

The major indexes traded in positive territory but were off the day's highs at midafternoon, as turnover continued to track lower across the board.The Nasdaq was up 0.4%, the Dow 0.3% and the S&P 500 0.2%. The NYSE tacked on 0.1%, after spending much of the day in the red.Investors were digesting a worse-than-expected September reading for the Empire State Manufacturing Survey Index, as well as a more upbeat manufacturing report from the Fed. The Fed said industrial production gained modestly in August and the manufacturing sector expanded for the 12th time in 14 months.The health care sector led the market, with hospital, wholesale drugs-supplies, research equipment-services and systems-equipment industry groups among the day's best.Cable programmer Discovery Communications (DISCA) was up 2% in strong volume after hitting an all-time high of 42.11 early Wednesday. The stock has cleared resistance around 40.Israeli chip developer EZchip Semiconductor (EZCH) rose 4% in fast trade. The stock is extended after rebounding off its 10-week moving average.

Charter Communications (CHTR) is testing a live-TV streaming service that starts at just under $20 with no sports content.Time Warner's (TWX) HBO, meanwhile, may be heading to Hulu.Charter, which brands its online service Spectrum Stream, says the base package includes local broadcast channels and 25 cable networks, including AMC, CNN, A&E, History, TNT and Discovery (DISCA).A $12 monthly add-on package includes ESPN channels, NBC Sports, and Bloomberg news. A $15 monthly option includes movie channels.Dish Network (DISH) launched its Sling streaming service at $20 in January 2015 with Walt Disney's (DIS) ESPN, but lacked local TV stations from the four broadcast networks.Charter's Spectrum Stream service, if commercially launched, would also compete with AT&T's (T) DirecTV Now, which starts at $35, as well as Hulu and Sony's web offering.Verizon Communications (VZ) has signaled that it could launch a video streaming service in the second half of 2017.IBD'S TAKE: Charter stock is up about 15% in 2017 but is trading near its 50-day moving average. Charter stock has a technical buy point of 341.60. Learn more at IBD Stock Checkup.Hulu is a joint venture of Twenty-First Century Fox (FOXA), Disney, and Comcast (CMCSA). Time Warner acquired a 10% stake in Hulu last year.AT&T, which is seeking regulatory approval to acquire Time Warner for $85 billion, has offered a free year of HBO in some DirecTV Now promotions. Time Warner also sells HBO as a stand-alone online product for $15 monthly.RELATED:Sprint Jumps On Comcast-Charter Wireless TalksComcast, Charter Fall; Longtime Industry Bull Downgrades Sector

X Maybe honesty isn't always the best policy? Walt Disney (DIS) Chief Executive Bob Iger slogged through an array of ESPN-related questions on late Tuesday's earnings call after the sports cable giant logged another quarter of subscriber declines. His bullish reaffirmations hearkened back to calls of earnings past, after he first disclosed in August 2015 that ESPN had sustained subscriber losses."Give us a little bit of credit for being very candid with you on an earnings call two summers ago," he told analysts, asserting that "we had our eyes wide open" about ESPN's issues, which allowed the company to deal with them head-on.Disney shares fell in late trade after ending Tuesday's regular session up 0.6% to 112.07 on the stock market today.Overall, Disney turned in a mixed quarter, falling short of second-quarter revenue forecasts late Tuesday with 3% growth to $13.34 billion. Profit of $1.50 per share marked a 10% year-over-year gain, ahead of estimates for 4% EPS growth.The entertainment heavyweight's media networks revenue, which includes both broadcast and cable TV, rose 3%, while operating income fell 3%. Programming costs also weighed on ESPN; cable networks' operating income fell 3%. The Disney Channels and Freeform, which appeal to children, teens and young adults, also lost subscribers during that period.Iger has his eyes on the future, as more people get their sports scores and highlights from mobile devices.While "there's nothing we can really do to slow that down," he said it's important for the network to participate in the new wave of technology. That's translated to development of ESPN's apps, its upcoming streaming platform powered by BAMTech and the network's presence on over-the-top "skinny" bundles, which Iger says benefit from the inclusion of ESPN."They've concluded that launching without ESPN is very challenged," he said on the call, adding, however, that despite "really nice growth," subscriber growth on streaming platforms has not made up for traditional cable-package subscriber losses.ESPN found itself in the headlines late last month when it laid off around 100 on-air personalities, another reminder of the troubles facing the traditional pay TV landscape."We're not sitting on our hands," said Iger.Disney's TV woes aside, Iger predictably lauded the studio's many box office successes, calling attention to "Rogue One" and "Beauty and the Beast," each of which have brought in at least $1 billion globally.Still, theatrical results were only "comparable" to the prior-year quarter due to the strength of "The Force Awakens" and "Zootopia" in 2016, according to the earnings release. Studio revenue dipped 1%, while operating income grew 21%.The theme parks segment logged the greatest revenue growth, up 9%. Operating income grew 20%, thanks to higher attendance and more spending on food and drink.Lastly, revenue at Disney's consumer products and interactive media unit dropped 11%, as strong "Frozen" and "Star Wars" sales last year provided tough comparisons. Operating income grew 3%.Up until last week, shares had been on a fairly steady upward march, making their way back up to 2015 highs. But Disney tumbled last week, falling below a buy point and its 50-day moving average.That was part of a broader media stock sell-off, spurred by sector jitters about ad revenue and subscriber losses following quarterly results from Viacom (VIAB), Time Warner (TWX) and others, plus the introduction of Hulu's live-TV beta service. (Disney is a joint owner of Hulu.)Broadly, investors appear to remain nervous about the power of cord-cutting and the state of the traditional pay TV system.During the session, Viacom fell 0.5%, while Time Warner sank 0.3%. 21st Century Fox (FOXA), which will report earnings on Wednesday, dipped 0.6%.Discovery Communications' (DISCA) results Tuesday revealed a "slight decline" in subscribers in its U.S. networks segment. Discovery shares retreated 2.2%.RELATED:Disney Earnings Preview: Movie Magic Vs. TV Static

The competition to attract eyeballs got more intense Tuesday as the YouTube unit of Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL) has announced the launch of YouTube TV."Half the cost of cable with zero commitments" said the announcement. For $35 a month, with no commitments or long-term contracts, YouTube TV will include live streaming of ABC, CBS, NBC, Fox, ESPN and about 30 of the biggest cable TV channels."YouTube TV will be available soon in the largest U.S. markets and will quickly expand to cover more cities across the country," YouTube said in a blog post.By visiting tv.youtube.com, consumers can sign up to find out when they'll launch in designated markets.Alphabet stock closed Tuesday at 844.93, down 0.6% on the stock market today.IBD'S TAKE: New products or services are part of the N in IBD's CAN SLIM investing system. Strong earnings growth (the C and A in the CAN SLIM System) is the No. 1 factor to look for in a stock, but new products or services are what ultimately generates stellar profitability.The $35 price includes six accounts, so that each user receives a personalized account and recommendations. The service will also allow users to record shows, which will be stored in the cloud."Your cloud DVR can record as many shows as you want, simultaneously, without using precious data or space on your phone and we'll store each of your recordings for nine months," Google said.Missing from the YouTube TV streaming lineup are channels from Viacom (VIAB), Turner Broadcasting, AMC Networks (AMCX) and Discovery Communications (DISCA).RELATED:Comcast, YouTube Set-Top App Deal Excludes New 'Unplugged' Service

XHere's your Investing Action Plan for Tuesday: what you need to know as an investor for the coming day. Dow Jones industrial average component Disney (DIS) has quietly formed a new base, just two months after breaking out of its last buy point. Fellow media giant 21st Century Fox (FOXA) is in a similar situation. Meanwhile, HD Supply (HDS)…

A Republican-led FCC may give AT&T (T), Comcast (CMCSA), Verizon Communications (VZ) and other pay TV providers more tools to counter the threat from Google TV, Hulu and other nascent internet video services, says a Cowen & Co. analyst.Ajit Pai, named chairman of the Federal Communications Commission by President Trump in January, has signaled that he'll scale back net neutrality rules that bar internet service providers from throttling, blocking or prioritizing web traffic. Under the Obama administration, the FCC sought more authority under utility-type regulations.Paul Gallant, an analyst at Cowen & Co., says "MVPDs" a regulatory term for pay TV incumbents, could seek interconnection fees from YouTube TV or Hulu. Gallant warned that MVPDs like AT&T, Comcast and Verizon might tap other tools to counter the threat from internet video services, also called over-the-top, or OTT, services. Broadband caps on data usage are another possibility, Gallant says.Google-parent Alphabet (GOOGL) on Tuesday announced YouTube TV, a $35 monthly paid subscription service. YouTube TV will offer access to all four major broadcast networks (CBS, ABC, NBC and Fox), and the cable channel offerings owned by their parent companies, such as sports channel ESPN.IBD'S TAKE: Quanta Services, Primerica and Nucor are on IBD's Leaderboard, which follows top stocks from their work on forming bases, through their breakouts, to their post-breakout action, up to the point where they start topping.Google aims to set itself apart with unlimited cloud storage for users to record content. Google will seek advertising revenue from YouTube TV, say analysts, who contend that $35 monthly fees might not be enough to make the service profitable.Hulu — a joint venture of Walt Disney (DIS), Fox-parent 21st Century Fox Entertainment (FOXA) and Comcast's NBCUniversal — is set to launch yet another live TV streaming service in the spring."With the rising OTT threat and a newly Republican Washington, MVPDs may now have greater incentive and ability to employ tactics to manage the threat from OTT," Gallant said in a research report. "Whether they take these steps — and whether it draws influential companies like Google, Facebook (FB), Walt Disney, Fox and others into the net neutrality debate — could be important for the longer-term balance of power within the internet ecosystem.""We suspect the new FCC will be much more open to ISPs charging interconnection fees to high bandwidth services, mainly video providers," Gallant added.He says Google could respond by imposing a "Cable Company X Tax" on its subscribers.YouTube TV will compete with other internet video services, such as AT&T's DirecTV Now and Dish Network's (DISH) Sling. YouTube TV does not provide channels from Viacom (VIA), Time Warner's (TWX) Turner Broadcasting, Discovery (DISCA) , AMC Networks (AMCX) and Scripps Networks Interactive (SNI).Alphabet stock slipped a small fraction in the stock market today to 849.08 and is about flat since the YouTube streaming announcement.RELATED:$35 DirecTV Now Live Streaming Deals Lives On After Promotion EndsAT&T Streaming Foray Hits Snag; Did Apple Avoid Black Eye?Google Advertising Plans Key In YouTube TV Launch Vs. AT&T, Hulu

Federal regulators could launch a probe if Comcast (CMCSA), 21st Century Fox (FOXA) and Walt Disney (DIS) bring in Time Warner (TWX) as a fourth partner in Hulu, especially if the media quartet becomes much more selective in licensing content to Web video streamer Netflix (NFLX).
So says Paul Gallant, an analyst at Guggenheim Partners.

Gallant notes that the Department of Justice in 2012 reportedly launched an antitrust investigation involving nascent over-the-top (OTT) online video services and the broadband policies of cable TV companies.
Even though Hulu is much smaller than Netflix, plans involving Hulu could raise alarm, says Gallant.

"It may well be the case that media company executives have not privately discussed restricting the sale of content to OTTs," said Gallant in a research report. "But given the growing public discussion around this issue — highlighted by Time Warner's comments and its possible Hulu move — it would not surprise us if the DOJ began an investigation for any indication of coordination regarding OTT."

One wild card is whether the media companies go ahead and license content to a formidable new entrant, such as Apple (AAPL). A Web TV service from Apple has long been speculated, though another analyst on Tuesday cast some doubt.
Time Warner reportedly is in talks to be the fourth partner in money-losing Hulu.
Disney, 21st Century Fox and cable TV firm Comcast, which controls NBCUniversal, are co-owners of Hulu.
Comcast is barred from taking part in Hulu's management until 2018, under conditions that regulators set on its 2011 acquisition of NBCU.
Disney disclosed higher Hulu losses in its Q3 earnings.
Programming Fees At Risk
While Netflix's subscribers continue to grow, pay-TV companies have been losing customers, putting the programming fees that media giants garner from Comcast and others at risk.

Some analysts have cautioned that pulling content from Netflix might not be the best strategic move, since Netflix pays for the content. Media firms' subscription video-on-demand revenue is much smaller than pay-TV revenue.

Time Warner and Fox have been the most open about rethinking their SVOD (subscription video on demand) licensing plans. Viacom (VIA) has cut back on content provided to Neflix. CBS, Disney and Comcast all licensed new shows to Netflix in Q3.

Media companies might not have a united front. Disney's three-year movie deal with Netflix kicks in during 2016. CBS (CBS) Chief Executive Leslie Moonves, at an investor conference Nov. 11, said, "Netflix is not the Antichrist."

Amid speculation that he's about to use his stakes in Discovery (DISCA), Starz (STRZA), Lionsgate (LGF) and Liberty Media (LMCA) to roll up smaller content providers, Liberty Chairman John Malone last week said that his biggest recent mistake was not launching a hostile takeover of Netflix when its shares plummeted in 2011 following a price hike.

Millennials are leading the small-screen trend. Although they account for only about 20% of total pay TV subscribers, big cable and satellite television companies Comcast (CMCSA), Time Warner Cable (TWC), Dish Network (DISH) and…

Morgan Stanley analyst Benjamin Swinburne said "the three-headed monster of (Google's  (GOOGL) YouTube, Netflix, and Facebook (FB)" gives U.S. media companies good reason to invest in overseas content…

Stocks wobbled at the open, then scrambled to healthy gains Tuesday, even as Europe's markets reversed to mild losses. The Nasdaq powered up 0.8% as biotechs and drugmakers rebounded with a vengeance. The S&P 500 climbed 0.7%. The Dow Jones industrials pulled up 0.4%.
Volume started mixed in the stock market today, 13% higher on the Nasdaq and a fraction lower on the NYSE, relative to trade at the same time Monday.

Housing news was also mixed, with Case Shiller's 20-City Home Price index up 5% in August. That was equal to or better than July's gain, which the group trimmed to 4.9%, from 5%. Consensus estimates had looked for a 5.3% increase.

Consumer views were less conflicted, with the Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index hitting 103 for September. That was a nice step up from August's revised 101.3 tally, and far above consensus estimates for a dial down to 96.

In stocks, Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) led the Dow, up 2% after Deutsche Bank upgraded the stock to buy, from hold, and held its price target steady at 110. McDonald's (MCD) was next in the Dow lineup, rising more than 1% on a Credit Suisse upgrade.
Nasdaq 100 companies Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Discovery Communications (DISCA) fell 4% and 3%, respectively. Yahoo (YHOO) bolstered the index with a nearly 6% gain.
Japan-based stocks were under some stress after Tokyo's Nikkei 225 dropped 4.1% in Tuesday's session. Toyota Motor (TM) and Honda Motor (HMC) each slipped more than 1%. Sony (SNE) fell more than 3%.
India-based banks trended higher after the country's central bank trimmed interest rates by a half-percent. HDFC Bank (HDB) and Icici Bank (IBN) each rose more than 2%.

Among the morning's wild early moves, thinly traded life insurer Phoenix (PNX) spiked 146% after a buyout offer from Nassau Reinsurance Group. Esperion Therapeutics (ESPR) dived 34%. The Ann Arbor, Mich.-based biotech gave an update on the design of the phase three trials for its ETC-1002 oral cholesterol treatment. Pollution control service provider Team (TISI) tumbled 19% after guiding its fiscal first-quarter revenue and earnings below consensus forecasts.

Among leaders, Cal-Maine Foods (CALM) bounced nearly 4%, fighting to take back ground after its 12% dive on Monday. The gain left shares still below their 10-week moving average in a four-month consolidation.

AMN Healthcare Services (AHS) scouted out the low end, dropping 4%. That put the San Diego-based medical staffing operation down 16% this week. The stock tripped a sell signal by cutting below its 10-week moving average in heavy trade on Monday.

Beyond stocks, oil prices upshifted nearly 2%, lifting West Texas Intermediate back above $45 a barrel and Brent crude above $48. Gold remained a fraction lower near $1,130 an ounce.Stocks wobbled at the open, then scrambled to healthy gains Tuesday, even as Europe's markets reversed to mild losses. Hollywood is the Holy City of imagined threats — everything from asteroids to zombies, with rogue regimes, interstellar thugs and 50-foot women in between. One threat Tinseltown is downplaying is the rise of online outlets for film, television and video content. David Zaslav, president and CEO of Discovery Communications, told concerned analysts in a Q1 conference call last month that,…

Theater stocks suggest someone still goes out to the movies. Much has been made of how entertainment is changing. Sure, you can watch HBO on your Apple (AAPL) iPad and download films from Amazon.com (AMZN). But three cinema chains in IBD's Leisure-Movies & Related group — Carmike, Marcus and Reading — make its top 5 in stock performance over the…
Online providers Netflix (NFLX) and Amazon (AMZN) are in position to benefit from the switch from physical media to streaming media.
For the first time ever, Americans this year will pay more to rent and buy movies and TV shows online than for DVDs and Blu-ray Discs combined.
Comcast (CMCSA), Time Warner Cable (TWC) and other cable providers that offer movies on demand are also well positioned.

Legal, paid views of movies and other content will hit 3.4 billion views in 2012, IHS said in a report. That's about 1 billion units higher than the 2.4 billion DVDs/Blu-ray Discs it expects people to buy this year.
As recently as last year, physical media had a commanding lead. Consumers bought 2.6 billion DVDs and Blu-ray Discs in 2011, 86% above the 1.4 billion they bought online.

Netflix struggled last year after it lost Liberty Media Starz as a content provider, and tried to hike prices and split the company into two companies, an online streaming service and a physical DVD rental company.
Its shares plummeted 80% from a July 15 high of 304.79 to 62.37 on Dec. 2.
It has since recovered some of that lost ground. Shares have risen about 93% since the December low.
Netflix was trading up 0.3% at 119.07 midday.
Netflix, with 23 million customers, on Feb. 21 signed a multiyear deal with the Weinstein Co. for foreign language, documentary and other movies, including 2012 Academy Award nominee "The Artist."
Rival Amazon's online viewing service is available on TVs, notebooks and its Kindle Fire tablet. It offers 120,000 titles for purchase or rent.
On March 14, Amazon announced an agreement with Discovery Communications (DISCA) that lets Amazon customers stream Discovery Channel, TLC, Animal Planet and other Discovery network shows.
Amazon shares, which have hiked about 17% this year, rose 1.4% to 195.06 midday.
No. 1 cable company Comcast was up 1 penny at 29.90, and rival Time Warner Cable accelerated 0.3% to 80.40.
Coinstar's (CSTR) Redbox could lose ground as the transition from DVDs to streaming video accelerates.
Redbox hit a milestone of its own this month with the 2 billionth disc rental from its kiosks. Now, in a defensive move, it's moving into the streaming market.

On Feb. 6, it entered into a joint venture with No. 1 wireless service provider Verizon Communications (VZ) to offer movies on mobile media like tablets and smartphones. Verizon owns 65% of the venture.

Verizon slid 0.7% to 39.37, and Coinstar rose 5 cents to 61.05.Online providers Netflix (NFLX) and Amazon (AMZN) are in position to benefit from the switch from physical media to streaming media.For the first time ever, Americans this year will pay more to rent and buy movies and TV shows online than for DVDs and Blu-ray Discs combined.Comcast (CMCSA), Time Warner Cable (TWC) and other cable providers that offer movies on demand are also well positioned.Legal, paid views of movies and other content will hit 3.4 billion views in 2012, IHS said in a report. Google (GOOG) is a formidable competitor in most places. In China though, Baidu (BIDU) dominates the search realm. But Qihoo 360 (QIHU) is taking market away from both.

The Chinese browser maker's software is installed on 425 million PC desktops. The company also has about 120 million people talking and texting on its budget smartphones. And now it's expanding into search, having replaced Google's search tool in its browser.
The Chinese company was one of six names to rejoin the elite IBD 50 list in Monday's edition. It's No. 24.

The others were data management and storage firm CommVault Systems (CVLT) at No. 30; fleet fuel card issuer Wright Express (WXS) at No. 38; backup generator maker Generac Holdings (GNRC) at No. 42; bakery and restaurant chain Panera Bread (PNRA)at No. 44; documentary broadcaster Discovery Communications (DISCA) at No. 45; and the plastics and chemical firm PolyOne (POL) at No. 49.

Falling off to make room were: Tractor Supply (TSCO), Tibco Software (TIBX), Teradata (TDC), Petsmart (PETM), Davita (DVA), Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) and Novo Nordisk (NVO).Google (GOOG) is a formidable competitor in most places. Lululemon Athletica (LULU), a rival of Nike (NKE) and Under Armour (UA), was upgraded Friday, while banking giant Wells Fargo (WFC) got a lower price target and Seagate Technology (STX) was downgraded. Lululemon was upgraded to outperform by Credit Suisse. The athletic apparel maker has been gaining share against Under Armour in key demographics such as upper-income teens, though Nike…

Comcast (CMCSA) aims to boost international revenue, with M&A an option, NBCUniversal's chief executive said at a financial conference on Wednesday.Comcast, which owns a cable TV network and entertainment giant NBCU, aims to catch up with Walt Disney (DIS), 21st Century Fox and others outside America, said Stephen Burke, NBCU's CEO, speaking at a Bank of America Merrill Lynch media and entertainment conference in Beverly Hills, Calif.NBCU on Wednesday forged a movie distribution deal with China-based Alibaba's (BABA) new Web streaming service.Burke said NBCU's "Fast and Furious 7" movie grossed $400 million at the box office in China."With growth in China, India and Latin America, you want a higher percentage of revenue coming from overseas," said Burke, noting that Comcast's cable TV business is all domestic. Liberty Global (LBTYA) is the biggest cable TV player in Europe."There are very few companies with a $150 billion market cap with so little of their revenue coming from outside the U.S.," Burke said. "We see it as a huge opportunity. I think whether it's M&A activity or organic growth, international is a huge opportunity for us and it's something we'll pursue over the next five to 10 years."Comcast also is building a $3.3 billion Universal theme park in Beijing with local partners.Burke said NBCU garners some 20% of revenue internationally. Discovery Communications (DISCA), with 51% of 2014 revenue outside the U.S., has the most international exposure. Fox (FOXA) garnered 33% of revenue outside America, followed by Time Warner (TWX) at 30%, Viacom (VIA) at 26% and Disney at 25%. Growing international revenue is key for media firms amid falling TV ratings and advertising woes, says MoffettNathanson.Burke said Comcast is interested in acquiring more live sports content and is investing in new content for millennials as video viewing habits shift to the Internet.

When Comcast launches a Web-based TV service this fall, first in Boston, it'll be an acid test for another spin of the "skinny bundle" — a lower-priced TV package with limited channels. Apple (AAPL) will pay attention, analysts say, because its much-anticipated Web-TV service may resemble Comcast's in some ways, if as expected it's launched in 2016. The launch depends…
What cable channels make the cut and are included in Apple's (AAPL) expected Web TV service could take on more significance after the recent sell-off in media and entertainment stocks.

Apple, it's widely reported, has been in talks with programmers to offer a slimmed-down bundle of TV networks. While Apple is said to be keen on including live broadcast networks NBC, ABC, CBS and Fox, its plans for cable TV channels remain unknown.
UBS analyst Doug Mitchelson, in a research report Tuesday on Discovery (DISCA), calls Apple's Web TV launch a wild card for cable channels.

Discovery is perhaps best known for its popular "Shark Week" programming, but Discovery stock is down nearly 35% in the past year as the pay-TV and video content industry goes through a transition, with more viewers moving to Internet services and dropping cable services, or cutting the cord.

"Key for (Discovery) shares will be continuing ratings strength, investors gaining comfort with the pace of decline for the U.S. pay-TV bundle, whether Discovery will be included in any Apple TV OTT (over the top, or Web TV) offering (at reasonable economics), and the health of the TV ad market this fall," he said in the report.

When Dish Network (DISH) launched it's limited-channel, $20-per-month Sling Web TV service in January, it left out broadcast networks as well as cable channels from AMC Networks (AMCX), CBS (CBS), Discovery, 21st Century Fox (FOXA), Comcast's NBCUniversal and Viacom (VIA).

Referring to Sling, RBC Capital analyst David Bank said in a May research report: "Many are concerned this is the beginning of breaking down the bundle into a more a la carte skinny version that has only those networks the consumer most wants." Viewership of cable channels, meanwhile, continue to fall, according to ratings tracker Nielsen.

The biggest media firms that own broadcast TV networks as well as popular cable channels, such as Disney's (DIS) ESPN sports channel, might be best-positioned to hammer out a deal with Apple. However, Apple's talks with Comcast (CMCSA), owner of NBCU, reportedly hit a rough patch earlier this year.
Apple is said to be mulling a Web TV service with about 25 channels, priced around $35 a month. The service had long been anticipated, but many observers don't see it becoming a reality this year.

CBS CEO Leslie Moonves in May said Apple is "is trying to change the universe a little bit as did Sling, as did Sony (SNE) (which is launching an Internet TV service). What Apple will offer ... is a more select group (of channels) for a lower price."
Apple's Web TV service has been delayed until 2016, Bloomberg reported, amid stalled negotiations with content companies and quality concerns over online video delivery.
Media stocks were torched in early August after Disney warned over over slowing revenue growth from affiliate fees and Discovery stopped a stock buyback.

Disney stock is down 12% since touching a record high of 122.08 on Aug. 4.What cable channels make the cut and are included in Apple's (AAPL) expected Web TV service could take on more significance after the recent sell-off in media and entertainment stocks.Apple, it's widely reported, has been in talks with programmers to offer a slimmed-down bundle of TV networks. While Apple is said to be keen on including live broadcast networks NBC, ABC, CBS and Fox, its plans for cable TV channels remain unknown.UBS analyst Doug Mitchelson, in a research report Tuesday on Discovery (DISCA), calls Apple's Web TV launch a wild card for cable channels.Discovery is perhaps best known for its popular "Shark Week" programming, but Discovery stock is down nearly 35% in the past year as the pay-TV and video content industry goes through a transition, with more viewers moving to Internet services and dropping cable services, or cutting the cord."Key for (Discovery) shares will be continuing ratings strength, investors gaining comfort with the pace of decline for the U.S. pay-TV bundle, whether Discovery will be included in any Apple TV OTT (over the top, or Web TV) offering (at reasonable economics), and the health of the TV ad market this fall," he said in the report.When Dish Network (DISH) launched it's limited-channel, $20-per-month Sling Web TV service in January, it left out broadcast networks as well as cable channels from AMC Networks (AMCX), CBS (CBS), Discovery, 21st Century Fox (FOXA), Comcast's NBCUniversal and Viacom (VIA).Referring to Sling, RBC Capital analyst David Bank said in a May research report: "Many are concerned this is the beginning of breaking down the bundle into a more a la carte skinny version that has only those networks the consumer most wants." Viewership of cable channels, meanwhile, continue to fall, according to ratings tracker Nielsen.The biggest media firms that own broadcast TV networks as well as popular cable channels, such as Disney's (DIS) ESPN sports channel, might be best-positioned to hammer out a deal with Apple. However, Apple's talks with Comcast (CMCSA), owner of NBCU, reportedly hit a rough patch earlier this year.Apple is said to be mulling a Web TV service with about 25 channels, priced around $35 a month. The service had long been anticipated, but many observers don't see it becoming a reality this year.CBS CEO Leslie Moonves in May said Apple is "is trying to change the universe a little bit as did Sling, as did Sony (SNE) (which is launching an Internet TV service). What Apple will offer ... is a more select group (of channels) for a lower price."Apple's Web TV service has been delayed until 2016, Bloomberg reported, amid stalled negotiations with content companies and quality concerns over online video delivery.Media stocks were torched in early August after Disney warned over over slowing revenue growth from affiliate fees and Discovery stopped a stock buyback.Disney stock is down 12% since touching a record high of 122.08 on Aug. 4.
What cable channels make the cut and are included in Apple's (AAPL) expected Web TV service could take on more significance after the recent sell-off in media and entertainment stocks.

Apple, it's widely reported, has been in talks with programmers to offer a slimmed-down bundle of TV networks. While Apple is said to be keen on including live broadcast networks NBC, ABC, CBS and Fox, its plans for cable TV channels remain unknown.
UBS analyst Doug Mitchelson, in a research report Tuesday on Discovery (DISCA), calls Apple's Web TV launch a wild card for cable channels.

Discovery is perhaps best known for its popular "Shark Week" programming, but Discovery stock is down nearly 35% in the past year as the pay-TV and video content industry goes through a transition, with more viewers moving to Internet services and dropping cable services, or cutting the cord.

"Key for (Discovery) shares will be continuing ratings strength, investors gaining comfort with the pace of decline for the U.S. pay-TV bundle, whether Discovery will be included in any Apple TV OTT (over the top, or Web TV) offering (at reasonable economics), and the health of the TV ad market this fall," he said in the report.

When Dish Network (DISH) launched it's limited-channel, $20-per-month Sling Web TV service in January, it left out broadcast networks as well as cable channels from AMC Networks (AMCX), CBS (CBS), Discovery, 21st Century Fox (FOXA), Comcast's NBCUniversal and Viacom (VIA).

Referring to Sling, RBC Capital analyst David Bank said in a May research report: "Many are concerned this is the beginning of breaking down the bundle into a more a la carte skinny version that has only those networks the consumer most wants." Viewership of cable channels, meanwhile, continue to fall, according to ratings tracker Nielsen.

The biggest media firms that own broadcast TV networks as well as popular cable channels, such as Disney's (DIS) ESPN sports channel, might be best-positioned to hammer out a deal with Apple. However, Apple's talks with Comcast (CMCSA), owner of NBCU, reportedly hit a rough patch earlier this year.
Apple is said to be mulling a Web TV service with about 25 channels, priced around $35 a month. The service had long been anticipated, but many observers don't see it becoming a reality this year.

CBS CEO Leslie Moonves in May said Apple is "is trying to change the universe a little bit as did Sling, as did Sony (SNE) (which is launching an Internet TV service). What Apple will offer ... is a more select group (of channels) for a lower price."
Apple's Web TV service has been delayed until 2016, Bloomberg reported, amid stalled negotiations with content companies and quality concerns over online video delivery.

Google's pricing and content lineup for YouTube TV — its planned live-TV subscription-streaming service — has Wall Street analysts abuzz over implications for the likes of AT&T, Time Warner, Comcast, and Hulu parents Walt Disney and Fox, as well as second-tier media companies excluded from new online packages.YouTube is already a big moneymaker for Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL). One big question is how much Google-owned YouTube's advertising revenue will grow as it adds live TV and original content for paid subscription services.Google on Tuesday took the wraps off YouTube TV, which will be "available soon in the largest U.S. markets and will quickly expand to cover more cities across the country," the company said in a blog.YouTube TV will compete with other internet video services, such as AT&T's (T) DirecTV Now and Dish Network's (DISH) Sling. Hulu — a joint venture of Disney (DIS), Fox parent 21st Century Fox Entertainment (FOXA) and Comcast's (CMCSA) NBCUniversal — is set to launch yet another live TV streaming service in the spring.YouTube TV will offer access to all four major broadcast networks (CBS, ABC, NBC and Fox), and the cable channel offerings owned by their parent companies, such as sports channel ESPN. Missing from the content lineup, though, are channels from Viacom (VIA), Time Warner's (TWX) Turner Broadcasting, Discovery (DISCA), AMC Networks (AMCX) and Scripps Networks Interactive (SNI).YouTube TV starts at $35 monthly, similar to AT&T's DirecTV Now service, but it's unclear whether YouTube's will eke out profits even with fewer channels. Alphabet stock rose 1.4% to 856.75 in the stock market today.IBD'S TAKE: Alphabet stock is up 8% in 2017 and has cleared an 824.40 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. The stock is still in a buy range. Learn more about Alphabet's growth trends and chart at IBD Stock Checkup.Here are some analyst take-aways from Google's announcement:RELATED:$35 DirecTV Now Live Streaming Deals Lives On After Promotion EndsAT&T Streaming Foray Hits Snag; Did Apple Avoid Black Eye?

Verizon Communications (VZ) and media baron John Malone's Charter Communications (CHTR) are exploring a merger, according to multiple reports Thursday.Media baron Malone's Liberty Broadband (LBRDA) is the biggest shareholder in Charter, which acquired Time Warner Cable in 2015, emerging as the No. 2 cable TV firm behind Comcast (CMCSA). Malone and Liberty Media's assets include stakes in Discovery (DISCA), Starz, QVC Group and Lions Gate Entertainment (LGF). Malone is chairman of Liberty Media.In Europe, Malone-controlled cable TV firm Liberty Global (LBTYA) has forged partnerships with wireless firms such as Vodafone Group (VOD). Liberty Global and Vodafone backed away from merger talks in 2015, however. Malone, a cable TV industry pioneer, led Tele-Communications Inc. in the 1980s and 90s. The old AT&T acquired TCI in 1999, and most of its assets eventually were sold off to cable firms.Charter stock shot up 7.4% to close at 333.15 in the stock market today, at a record high for the fifth straight trading day as M&A rumors have swirled in the communications services field. Verizon shares ended 1.3% lower Thursday. Verizon stock slumped 4.4% Tuesday on disappointing 2017 guidance and is trading at two-month lows.The Wall Street Journal initially reported that Verizon had approached Charter, with the Financial Times following up by saying the companies have hired advisors for merger talks.IBD'S TAKE: Seacoast Banking, Inphi, GrubHub and NetEase are among IBD's Sector Leaders, a list that highlights the best stocks in 33 sectors. All Sector Leaders show outstanding earnings and sales growth in recent quarters.Speculation over Verizon-Charter negotiations first surfaced in mid-December. Verizon's CEO Lowell McAdam told sell-side analysts in a meeting that a merger would make "industrial sense."Verizon also has been linked to Dish Network (DISH), which had wireless assets but needs a partner. Dish stock lost 6.8% Thursday on the Charter report.Charter and Comcast have an agreement to lease access to Verizon's wireless network on a wholesale basis. Comcast plans to launch wireless services in mid-2017.Merging with a cable TV firm would dovetail with Verizon's strategy to launch 5G wireless services. 5G services require connections to fiber-optic networks in dense urban areas."We believe a combination of Verizon and Charter is feasible but difficult on the financials, but Comcast's overall size and NBC ownership make a deal with Verizon a nonstarter as the regulatory review process would likely be quite difficult," JPMorgan analyst Philip Cusick wrote Monday in a broad research report on telecom industry M&A scenarios.Speaking at a Lions Gate Entertainment Corp. investor event in early January, Malone speculated that cable firms could buy T-Mobile US (TMUS). He also suggested that in a Trump administration maybe even Charter and Comcast could merge. The Obama administration blocked Comcast's purchase of Time Warner Cable in 2015.RELATED:Disney A Cure For Verizon Woes? Dish Deal Seen Less LikelyVerizon, Comcast Merger Talk A 'Nonstarter,' Says JPMorganCash Key In SoftBank-Sprint 'Knockout' Offer For T-Mobile?Verizon M&A Talk Swirls; Charter Stock Up, Yahoo Down

The Nasdaq toggled above and below the break-even line near midday Tuesday, while the S&P 500 and the Dow held steady gains. The Nasdaq was down a fraction just before noon. The Dow Jones industrial average was ahead 0.3% and the S&P 500 was up 0.2%. Trading was steady, up 18% on the Nasdaq and 16% higher on the NYSE…

Media giant Time Warner (TWX), parent of Turner Broadcasting, Warner Bros. Entertainment and Home Box Office, reported earnings that topped analyst expectations on strong growth in its TV networks' ad sales.The report out before the market opened Wednesday drove its stock price up above its 50-day line in early trading in more than four times normal volume.The second largest U.S. media conglomerate's adjusted earnings per share rose 8.9% to 86 cents. That beat Wall Street's outlook by 4 cents, the fifth straight time it's topped views.Revenue fell 3.3% to $6.84 billion, just under what analysts expected.The Media-Diversified group, ranked No. 43 on IBD's list of 197 industry groups, also includes CBS (CBS), which will report after the market closes Wednesday. Walt Disney (DIS) is on tap to announce results Thursday.Tuesday, Time Warner peer Discovery Communications (DISCA) cut its revenue outlook for the year.Still, analysts project 9.5% earnings growth in the sector, according to data from Thomson Reuters, among the strongest gains of any group.Time Warner affirmed it still expects its 2012 earnings growth to be in the low double digits off of $2.89 a share in 2011. Analysts were looking for $3.20.Time Warner's earnings hike came after three straight periods of declining growth, from 40% to 16% to -2%.Chairman and CEO Jeff Bewkes said the company is on track to meet goals this year as the TV network business delivered double-digit operating income growth."This performance illustrates that out investments in content and technology are continuing to pay off," Bewkes said in a written statement. "We're experiencing good momentum across most of Turner's networks. TBS, for instance, was up 35% in prime time for adults 18-49 this quarter..."

Stocks pared gains Wednesday afternoon as Disney (DIS) fell sharply and mixed economic data spurred uncertainty over interest rates. The Nasdaq was up 0.7%, the S&P 500 climbed 0.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average edged up 0.1%. All were off session highs. Volume in the stock market today was running well above Tuesday's levels on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq.

Media stocks were among the hardest hit. Disney dropped 9%, weighing on the Dow, after reporting late Tuesday that revenue rose 5% in the latest quarter to $13.1 billion, below Wall Street estimates. The stock sliced through its 50-day moving average and fell as much as 3% below a 113.40 buy point of a flat base. Volume was the highest in at least a year, suggesting heavy institutional selling.
Discovery Communications (DISCA) was down 9%, hitting its lowest levels since February, after the cable operator also reported weaker-than-expected Q2 revenue.

On the upside, Mexican restaurant chain Chuy's Holdings (CHUY) soared more than 24% to a 52-week high after reporting that Q2 profit jumped 52% to 32 cents a share, accelerating for the second straight quarter and easily beating analysts' forecasts. Sales rose 19% to $75.4 million, also above views.
Volume was heavy as the stock retook a 28.14 buy point of a flat base.

In the IBD 50, Paycom Software (PAYC) popped 17%, retaking its 50-day line, after the provider of cloud-based personnel management software posted strong Q2 results late Tuesday. The stock had recently triggered a sell signal by falling more than 8% below a 35.96 buy point.

In economic news, payroll processor ADP said private employers added 185,000 jobs in July, below Econoday's estimate of 210,000 jobs. Stocks rose initially on sentiment that weak data may keep the central bank from raising interest rates. However, the Institute for Supply Management's index of service sector activity came in much stronger than expected last month, jumping 4.3 points to 60.3. Apple (AAPL) may replace your cable TV provider, but it's probably not going to be regulated like one. Apple has been delayed in launching a Web TV service. An Apple TV service could ramp up in late 2015 or 2016 if it gains rights to programming, analysts say. The Federal Communications Commission, meanwhile, is studying whether to give Internet video…
Calling CBS (CBS) programming a "must have" for any Internet video provider, including Apple (AAPL), Deutsche Bank Thursday upgraded the down-on-its-luck media stock to buy.
Apple on Wednesday unveiled new TV hardware, what it calls Apple TV, but did not say anything about its widely expected plans to launch a Web TV streaming service.

"CBS is a must-have network and we believe will likely be included in all skinny bundles that are introduced by existing players and new entrants," said Bryan Kraft, an analyst at Deutsche Bank, in a research report. "We are confident that to the extent Apple introduces a pay-TV service next year, it too will likely include CBS."

Media stocks have melted over worries that the pay-TV ecosystem will fall apart as young adults switch to online video and on-demand content. Walt Disney's (DIS) Q2 earnings warning about slowing revenue growth from affiliate fees — the payments that media firms garner from pay-TV companies — also sent media stocks down.

Apple reportedly has been in talks with programmers to offer a slimmed-down bundle of TV networks. While Apple is said to be keen on including live broadcast networks NBC, ABC, CBS and Fox, its plans for cable TV channels such as Discovery (DISCA) are not clear.

"While the market, at the moment, is hyper-focused on the risks from pay-TV subscribers shifting to smaller channel bundles and outright cord-cutting, we are less concerned with this risk, particularly as it relates to CBS," Kraft wrote.
CBS has been among the first to adopt a direct-to-consumer model among media firms, launching its own stand-alone Web streaming products, including broadcast TV and movie channel Showtime.
Kraft expects upside for CBS shares generally. He set a price target of 60 on the stock.
CBS was flat in midday trading in the stock market today, near 43.50.

Kraft wrote: "We see an inflection point in EPS growth with limited risk to estimates because cost pressures are abating, ad revenue expectations are achievable with catalysts benefiting the next year, Showtime's OTT service should become an earnings driver in 2016, (advertising) scatter pricing is strong in Q3, CBS is significantly undermonetizing the pay-TV ecosystem, and CBS is best positioned to grow from a shift toward smaller bundles and new entrants (Apple)."Calling CBS (CBS) programming a "must have" for any Internet video provider, including Apple (AAPL), Deutsche Bank Thursday upgraded the down-on-its-luck media stock to buy.Apple on Wednesday unveiled new TV hardware, what it calls Apple TV, but did not say anything about its widely expected plans to launch a Web TV streaming service."CBS is a must-have network and we believe will likely be included in all skinny bundles that are introduced by existing players and new entrants," said Bryan Kraft, an analyst at Deutsche Bank, in a research report. Apple is refining its fashion sensibilities with the Wednesday debut of Apple Watch Hermes, a luxury designer collaboration with the maker of Birkin bags. But it is not the only one advancing on the stylish smartwatch space.
Signet Jewelers (SIG) CEO Mark Light told IBD that the company — which owns Kay Jewelers, Jared and Zales — might be testing smartwatch sales in stores soon.
"We're hoping there's something in stores in the first half of next year," said Light, referring to products from Signet's watch manufacturing partners, though he did not specify which.

Kay, Jared and Zales all carry Movado (MOV), the Swiss watchmaker that said during its late August earnings call that it would introduce smartwatches around the holiday season. Movado notably brought on former Apple (AAPL) veteran Jo An Lawson as its general manager of wearable devices last December.

Light also hinted that Signet will develop its own smart accessories beyond timepieces: "On the jewelry side, we're initiating with manufacturing partners, the tech department, the merchandise department. We're looking at several opportunities."

"When it comes to jewelry, our hopes are that we're going to try to be one of the first people out there," Light told IBD on Wednesday. "As the leader in diamond jewelry, we expect to be the ones to be the first to innovate."
RBC Capital Markets initiated Signet with an outperform rating and 160 price target Wednesday.

Meanwhile, in the broadcast TV industry, Deutsche Bank on Thursday upgraded CBS (CBS) to buy, calling the down-on-its-luck media company's programming a "must have" for any Internet video provider, including Apple.
Apple on Wednesday unveiled new TV hardware, what it calls Apple TV, but did not say anything about its widely expected plans to launch a Web TV streaming service.

"CBS is a must-have network and we believe will likely be included in all skinny bundles that are introduced by existing players and new entrants," said Bryan Kraft, an analyst at Deutsche Bank, in a research report. "We are confident that to the extent Apple introduces a pay-TV service next year, it too will likely include CBS."
CBS' stock trades 31% below a 52-week high of 63.95.

Federal Communications Commission Chairman Tom Wheeler brought the programming dispute between satellite TV broadcaster Dish Network (DISH) and Sinclair Broadcast Group (SBGI) to a quick end, but the industry's top regulator won't have the same official clout to intervene if Dish and Viacom (VIA) reach an impasse in upcoming negotiations.

The FCC's authority to step in applies only to "retransmission" negotiations involving broadcast signals and not to pure cable TV channel owners such as Viacom, Time Warner (TWX), Discovery (DISCA) and AMC Networks (AMCX), says Guggenheim Partners in a report. Comcast (CMCSA) and Discovery recently hammered out a deal in a closely watched negotiation.
In response to competition from Netflix (NFLX) and complaints over rising monthly bills, pay-TV providers have become tougher negotiators when programming deals with media firms come up for renewal.

The FCC has the authority to step in on matters involving broadcasters such as Walt Disney (DIS) (which owns ABC), CBS (CBS), 21st Century Fox (FOXA), Sinclair, Nexstar Broadcasting Group (NXST) and Media General (MEG).
Dish Network had asked the FCC to get involved in its dispute with Sinclair.
Dish Network and Sinclair agreed late Wednesday to extend negotiations and suspend a blackout that had prevented more than 5 million Dish customers in 36 states from getting their local stations.
"The FCC will remain vigilant while the negotiations continue," said Wheeler in a statement.
The FCC last intervened in 2013, when CBS and Time Warner Cable (TWC) faced off. TWC paid a price, losing 190,000 subscribers.
Dish Network has had disputes with CBS, 21st Century Fox and Time Warner's Turner Broadcasting unit.
However, a showdown looms with Viacom, say analysts. Viacom has 24 cable channels, usually offered in TV bundles.
A programming contract renewal with Dish Network is "critical" for Viacom, said Deutsche Bank, which last week lowered its price target on the media and entertainment company.
Dish could drop Viacom content, said brokerage MoffettNathanson in a research report.

Dish Network stock was up more than 1% in early trading in the stock market today, while Sinclair stock was up 2.5%. Viacom's shares were up 2% early Thursday.Federal Communications Commission Chairman Tom Wheeler brought the programming dispute between satellite TV broadcaster Dish Network (DISH) and Sinclair Broadcast Group (SBGI) to a quick end, but the industry's top regulator won't have the same official clout to intervene if Dish and Viacom (VIA) reach an impasse in upcoming negotiations.The FCC's authority to step in applies only to "retransmission" negotiations involving broadcast signals and not to pure cable TV channel owners such as Viacom, Time Warner (TWX), Discovery (DISCA) and AMC Networks (AMCX), says Guggenheim Partners in a report. Women who are new in a job are slightly more ambitious than men. But "for women who had more than two years on the job, aspiration and confidence plummeted 60% and 50%, respectively," says a study in the Harvard Business Review. "These declines came independent of marriage and motherhood status, and compared with much smaller changes for men." Women lose ambition because they feel that their supervisors don't support them and they see that they don't fit "the typical stereotype of success within (the) company."Women who are new in a job are slightly more ambitious than men. But "for women who had more than two years on the job, aspiration and confidence plummeted 60% and 50%, respectively," says a study in the Harvard Business Review. Twinkies maker Hostess Brands is going out of business but designer cupcake startups might have staying power, fueled in part by social media.

Three years ago, the New York Times was already writing headlines like "A Late-Adopter to the Cupcake Phenomenon." But specialty cupcake stores kept proliferating, a long time after Manhattan's Magnolia Bakery was credited with starting the craze in 1996.

"The cupcake business has been really steady; it's stayed the same," said Katherine Kallinis Berman. She's half of the team of sisters that runs Georgetown Cupcake in Washington, D.C., and this week pre-opened a new branch in Beverly Hills, Calif., to much fanfare. "Even when times are tough, it's not hard to splurge on a cupcake, which is only $2.75, but it really is a gourmet cupcake."

"Facebook (FB) and Twitter are two really great resources for us," Berman said, adding that they've helped build a fan base for the store's more than 100 cupcake flavors from Butterscotch Pudding to Lavender Earl Grey Teacake. Though it doesn't hurt that the sisters have a TV show, DC Cupcakes, on Discovery Communications' (DISCA) TLC. Nor that cupcake blogs and Pinterest boards clog the arteries of the Internet, keeping the dream alive and iced. Blog directory Technorati counts 459 blogs relating to cupcakes out of 14,197 food blogs.

The average food blogger has 763 Twitter followers, while the most active 10% have an average of 4,656 each, according to a 694-person food blogging survey in February by Foodista and Zephyr Adventures. The bloggers cited an average of 817 Facebook fans and likes and the top 10% an average of 6,059.

Georgetown Cupcake, which opened branches in New York and Boston earlier this year, claims 56,409 Twitter followers and 212,719 Facebook likes. The small-business bakers egged on interest during election season with a cupcake pool.
"The Democrats were ahead by 10% the entire time," Berman said. "I don't know if we could tell which way the election was going, but we could tell which party had the bigger sweet tooth."

Food trucks, too, have benefited from social networking and general hipness. A few years ago, Rutgers University professor Kathe Newman set about charting New York City gentrification by how many new cupcake stores opened in an area. This year, an issue of the Journal of Urban Design featured a study by Ginette Wessel noting that "place, social media and mobility in this food truck phenomenon are the basis for a methodological approach that aims to uncover new social dynamics occurring in cities."

The fate of iconic mass-market cupcakes is far different from that of some select pricey-cupcake entrepreneurs. Hostess Brands has made Twinkies cakelets — "golden sponge cake with creamy filling" — since they were invented in 1930. Production reportedly ceased Friday as the bankrupt food company sought court permission to end business after failing to get the wage and benefit cuts it sought from thousands of striking workers. A hearing was set for Monday.

Twinkies might have had their heyday long before the arrival of the Internet and social media fandom. But it certainly didn't take long for 1,985 eBay (EBAY) auctions to pop up selling boxes of Twinkies to distraught fans, including at prices as high as $5 million — with free shipping.Twinkies maker Hostess Brands is going out of business but designer cupcake startups might have staying power, fueled in part by social media.Three years ago, the New York Times was already writing headlines like "A Late-Adopter to the Cupcake Phenomenon." Netflix (NFLX) shares got a boost on the stock market today as Wall Street sees reasons why the streaming video service will stay ahead of rivals.Bank of America upgraded Netflix on Tuesday from neutral to buy with a price target of 722. That's a 30% premium from Monday's closing price.The analysts said Netflix's strong original content library will fuel further subscriber growth in the U.S. and internationally as well as fend off competitive threats from other services, which include the likes of Amazon (AMZN) and Hulu.Original content from Netflix includes "House of Cards," "Orange is the New Black" and Marvel's "Daredevil."And in the pipeline, Netflix has about 30 series planned, including three more Marvel series, a slew of animated series, and even a Chelsea Handler talk show.Shares rose 2% Tuesday in above average volume. Discovery Communications (DISCA) stock jumped Monday on speculation that the multichannel television producer is a takeover target.A report late Sunday by the Australian Financial Review said that 21st Century Fox (FOXA) held preliminary merger talks with Discovery about two weeks ago. A Fox spokesperson responded to the article, saying, "The story is categorically untrue." Discovery declined to comment.The idea that Discovery might be in play excited Wall Street."If the parties, as they maintain, are not talking, we think they ought to have a chat," Bernstein analyst Todd Juenger said in a research note Monday. "We believe a merger between FOXA and DISCA would make strategic sense on a number of levels."Discovery owns such channels as Discovery Channel, Animal Planet and Science, with such popular shows as "Gold Rush," "Deadliest Catch" and "MythBusters."The combination of Discovery and Fox would create a dominant player in international cable networks, he said. It would allow for a natural combination of the Discovery Channel and Fox's National Geographic channels, as well as Fox's Sky Sports networks and Discovery's Eurosport in Europe, Juenger said.Discovery stock was up 5% in midday trading on the stock market today, near 32.50. It had been up as much as 9% in morning trading but has been in a downtrend since August.On Thursday, Discovery reported its first year-over-year decline in earnings per share in eight quarters. Sales growth was the slowest for the company in seven quarters.In the December quarter, Discovery earned 38 cents a share, down 7% from the year-earlier quarter, on sales of $1.68 billion, up 9%. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were looking for 41 cents and $1.7 billion.

New Internet television services from Dish Network (DISH), Sony and possibly Apple are unlikely to please either potential cable TV cord-cutters or cord nevers, Bernstein Research said in a report Thursday.The over-the-top video services announced or rumored so far are too narrow for existing pay-TV subscribers and are too expensive for people who have opted not to subscribe to traditional pay-TV services, Bernstein analyst Todd Juenger said in the report.His findings were based on comments made at focus groups in New York City and San Francisco. The groups were composed of people who identified themselves as "highly likely to cut the cord in the next six months," as well as people who felt just the opposite.Based on the focus groups, Juenger is pessimistic on the prospects for Sling TV from Dish Network, PlayStation Vue from Sony (SNE) and a rumored Apple (AAPL) TV service."A strong body of evidence is emerging that suggests to us that none of these services are likely to gain much traction," he said. "Simply put, for existing pay-TV subscribers, the content is too limited (relative to the cost savings); and for cord-nevers, the price is too high (relative to the appeal of the content)."The OTT services are handicapped by having fewer networks in order to achieve a lower price, but not enough networks to make the service appealing."Cord-cutting, in large numbers, isn't likely to happen," Juenger said. "It's one of those ideas that sounds great in the abstract but crumbles when faced with the reality. OTT services seem poised to garner few subscribers, which is more good news than bad. We believe it's better for the pay-TV ecosystem to remain in the status quo than to add millions of OTT subscribers at the cost of blowing the whole system apart."One of the big problems with "skinny" TV bundles is that individuals differ on what the ideal package of networks should be.Content Companies Cutting InAs Dish and others are putting together online programming bundles, some content companies are making stand-alone subscription video-on-demand services. These include Time Warner 's (TWX) HBO Go service, set to launch next month on Apple TV hardware; CBS All Access; and Nickelodeon's Noggin from parent Viacom (VIAB).Complicating matters even more are subscription streaming video services like Netflix (NFLX), Amazon.com (AMZN) and Hulu, which offer original programming as well as licensed TV shows and movies.The concept of over-the-top television is appealing because many people hate their cable TV providers but are stuck with them unless an effective alternative emerges."The vitriol toward the cable companies was intense" in the focus groups, Juenger said. "A surprising number of participants are currently subscribing to pay-TV only because it is actually cheaper than buying high-speed Internet on its own."Bernstein rates Walt Disney (DIS), 21st Century Fox (FOXA) and Time Warner as outperform.It rates AMC Networks (AMCX), CBS (CBS), Discovery Communications (DISCA), and Scripps Networks Interactive (SNI) as market perform; and Viacom as underperform.RELATED:Apple building new set-top box for its Internet TV serviceSony pursues cord cutters with over-the-top TV service.

Netflix's (NFLX) decision Monday to abandon its plans to launch a separate website for DVD subscribers called Qwikster likely was driven by worse-than-expected customer defections.

Netflix faced an uprising of consumer discontent over its Sept. 18 announcement to split its DVD-by-mail and streaming video services. The move would have forced subscribers who used both services to manage separate accounts, rental queues and websites. That news came on top of price increases of as much as 60% for subscribers of both services.

"This (decision) signals higher churn than they expected," said Arvind Bhatia, an analyst with Sterne Agee. "They already once lowered expectations and I believe they'll lower them again for Q4 numbers. And I believe that next year's numbers also are too high."

On Sept. 15, Netflix projected a net loss of 590,000 subscribers in the U.S. in the third quarter, or 2.3% of its domestic subscriber base, as a result of the rate increase. And that was three days before it announced the Qwikster service and splitting its businesses.
"Nobody's recommending Netflix to anybody now," Bhatia said. "It's fair to say that word of mouth is only negative."
Netflix has been the butt of jokes recently on "Saturday Night Live" and online comedy sites like CollegeHumor.com.
Bhatia says Netflix's once-stellar brand has been tarnished. The flip-flopping on Qwikster has given investors jitters and created uncertainty for users, he says.
Netflix told subscribers it moved too fast, not that it did the wrong thing, Bhatia says. That raises the possibility that it could separate the two services down the road.
Netflix CEO Reed Hastings announced early Monday that the company was scrapping Qwikster.

"It is clear that for many of our members two websites would make things more difficult, so we are going to keep Netflix as one place to go for streaming and DVDs," Hastings wrote. "This means no change: one website, one account, one password ... in other words, no Qwikster."
Netflix shares initially jumped nearly 10% on the news, but closed down almost 5%, at 111.62.

"Consumers value the simplicity Netflix has always offered and we respect that," Hastings said in a statement. "There is a difference between moving quickly — which Netflix has done very well for years — and moving too fast, which is what we did in this case."
Netflix learned that "if it's not broken, don't fix it," said Daniel Ernst, an analyst with Hudson Square Research. "The Qwikster announcement made it harder to use a well-regarded service."
Qwikster was a "boneheaded move" by Netflix executives, said Charlie Wolf, an analyst at Needham & Co. "It made no sense to do this."
Netflix is slated to report its third-quarter results on Oct. 24.

"We don't know the numbers, but I suspect that there was a material percentage of subscribers who dropped the service after this move," Wolf said. "The fury (over Qwikster) was unbelievable. It was like throwing salt on a wound" after the price hike.

Netflix is going to have to work harder to keep existing customers, win back defectors and attract new users, Ernst says. Competition is starting to emerge on the streaming video front from Amazon.com (AMZN), Hulu and others.

Netflix's decision to can Qwikster is a positive move and should help repair the company's reputation, because it's listening to its customers now, says Vasily Karasyov, an analyst with Susquehanna Financial.

When Netflix made its announcement about Qwikster, many analysts called it Netflix's "New Coke moment." That turned out to be prophetic. The only difference is that Netflix didn't call its DVD service Netflix Classic.

Coca-Cola introduced a new formula for its flagship soft drink in 1985 called New Coke. It turned out to be one of the biggest blunders in corporate history. Responding to customer outcry, Coca-Cola reintroduced the original Coke as Coca-Cola Classic three months later. It discontinued New Coke a few years later.

Netflix's CEO said the company wanted to separate its services because it was concerned that the legacy DVD business would slow its transition to streaming video. But while it was probably a wise business decision, it angered subscribers.

Focusing on its future as a streaming video company, Netflix has been busy adding content to its service. In the last few weeks alone, Netflix has added movies from DreamWorks Animation (DWA) and TV shows such as AMC's "The Walking Dead" and the classic "The Wonder Years" to its roster. It also has expanded its content deals with NBC Universal and Discovery Communications (DISCA).Netflix's (NFLX) decision Monday to abandon its plans to launch a separate website for DVD subscribers called Qwikster likely was driven by worse-than-expected customer defections.Netflix faced an uprising of consumer discontent over its Sept. 18 announcement to split its DVD-by-mail and streaming video services. Apple (AAPL) has been trying for years to break into the Internet television business with plans to offer a package of basic cable channels that could serve as an alternative to traditional pay-TV services. But Apple hasn't been able to secure the content deals needed to make it happen.Now that Dish Network (DISH) and Sony (SNE) have blazed a trail with such services, Apple once again is looking to enter the over-the-top television business. Apple is now negotiating with TV programmers and has shown demos of its proposed service, Re/code reported Wednesday.Apple's talks with TV programmers are at an early stage, and details like pricing and timing still need to be worked out, Re/code said.Meanwhile, Apple's streaming video box, the Apple TV, is overdue for an upgrade. The Cupertino, Calif.-based company hasn't come out with a new version of the $99 set-top box in two years.Dish Network began rolling out its Sling TV service last month after earning rave reviews with its introduction at the 2015 International CES show in Las Vegas.For $20 a month, Sling TV will deliver live sports, lifestyle, family, news and information channels, video-on-demand entertainment and the best of online video to broadband-connected devices at home and on the go. The base package includes 12 channels: ESPN, ESPN2, TNT, TBS, Food Network, HGTV, Travel Channel, Adult Swim, Cartoon Network, Disney Channel, ABC Family and CNN. Dish also will sell add-on packs costing $5 a month focused on sports, news and kids channels.Sony's PlayStation Vue will launch soon with about 75 channels from CBS (CBS), Discovery Communications (DISCA), Fox (FOXA), NBCUniversal, Scripps Networks Interactive (SNI) and Viacom (VIAB). By the end of March, the subscription cloud TV service is expected to go live in four cities: New York, Philadelphia, Chicago and Los Angeles. Pricing has yet to be announced, but some reports say it could cost $60 to $80 a month.

Sony could be the comeback kid in a fighting video game: On Feb. 5, the company reported better-than-expected December-quarter results and upgraded its financial outlook for the fiscal year, which ends on March 31. Sony's  (SNE) U.S. stock bounced 11% on the news and is up more than 60% the past 12 months despite November's cyberattack on its film…

Time Warner's (TWX) upcoming negotiations to renew programming deals with pay-TV service operators will be key for the media and entertainment giant's growth prospects, analysts say.Time Warner, which on Wednesday reported Q4 earnings that topped estimates, has upcoming talks with Comcast (CMCSA), satellite TV broadcaster Dish Network (DISH) and Time Warner Cable (TWC). Federal regulators are reviewing the proposed Comcast-Time Warner Cable merger."The pivotal question for Time Warner investors is whether management will successfully complete the U.S. affiliate deals in 2015 needed to drive a dramatic acceleration," said UBS analyst Doug Mitchelson in a research report. "We expect TWX will be successful with renewals."Analysts say that the biggest content providers — such as Time Warner, Walt Disney (DIS) and Twenty-First Century Fox (FOXA) — may have an edge over smaller programmers as pay-TV distributors look to lower programming costs.Pay-TV companies are shifting to slimmer programming packages, offering consumers fewer channels either in new "over-the-top" Internet video services or in "broadband-first" deals. To target cord cutters looking for "a la carte" packages, Comcast, Cox Communications and AT&T (T) have stepped up promotions of cheaper, $40 to $50 monthly plans that feature high-speed Internet and basic TV — without ESPN, Discovery (DISCA) and other high-cost channels.Larger content firms have a better chance of having their cable networks included in slimmed down TV packages, analysts say. That's why Viacom (VIA) and CBS (CBS) are reportedly exploring a merger to gain more negotiating clout."(Time Warner's) outlook for growth beyond 2015 appears much more reliant on a meaningful acceleration in revenue growth, which is likely to require successful renegotiation of the last two major domestic (pay-TV) deals and highly successful box office performance," said Andy Hargreaves, analyst at Pacific Crest Securities, in a report. Time Warner owns the Warner Brothers film studio.Dish Network has rolled out a new TV Web-only offering called Sling. It's called "skinny" because the satellite TV broadcaster's Web-based offering includes only 12 channels, but for just $20 monthly.Dish's deal includes programming from Disney, Time Warner's Turner network, Scripps Networks Interactive (SNI) and AMC Network (AMCX). Left out of the Dish Sling TV package were the big four national TV networks — ABC, CBS, Fox and Comcast's NBCUniversal — as well as cable channels from CBS, Discovery, Fox, NBCU and Viacom.Some media firms plan to go it alone with their own Web offerings. Time Warner plans to sell HBO on the Webin 2015, and CBS has launched a subscription streaming service. The Web streaming services target young adults and other consumers that "cut the cord," industry jargon for the growing number of people that disconnect pay-TV service in favor of more affordable online video options and on-demand content.
Dreamworks Animation (DWA) shares popped in premarket trading Thursday on news of interest in the studio from toy maker Hasbro (HAS).
Dreamworks shares were up 19% after reports said Hasbro was in "advanced talks" with the studio known for the "Shrek" and "Kung Fu Panda" movies. The deal would involve cash and stock.
Hasbro shares were down 2.6% premarket on the stock market today.

In September, Japanese conglomerate SoftBank was reportedly in talks to buy Dreamworks for $32 per share. But just a few days later the Wall Street Journal reported that the talks cooled and Dreamworks gave up its stock gains on the news.
Hasbro has been working to become more of a media company as toy sales decline amid demand for electronics like smartphones, tablets and video game consoles.

The company has a joint venture with Discovery Communications (DISCA) called Discovery Family Channel, formerly the Hub Network. The station's shows feature products like My Little Pony, Transformers and other Hasbro toys.
Hasbro reduced its shares of the company to 40% from 50% in September.
The Leisure-Toys/Games/Hobby group is ranked No. 182 out of the 197 industry groups IBD tracks. But Dreamworks' Leisure-Movies & Related group is ranked No. 45.

Stocks opened Tuesday's session lower, as investors skittish over Europe's financial outlook reacted harshly to first-quarter earnings reports.The Nasdaq slipped 1%, the S&P 500 0.9% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.8%. Volume was up on the Nasdaq and down on the NYSE compared with the same time Monday.Aircraft components maker TransDigm Group (TDG) gapped up 2% in heavy trade, although it gave up some gains. Adjusted Q1 earnings soared 92% to $1.65 a share. Analysts' consensus was $1.46. The company also boosted its full-year earnings guidance by 10%, to between $6.23 and $6.57.The stock is extended 10% above a 118.31 buy point in a flat base.GNC Holdings (GNC) muscled up more than 2%, but remained 9% below its April 27 high. The vitamin, supplement and nutrition chain is 14% past a 33.82 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern in mid-March, when it also found support at the 50-day line.On the downside, Rackspace Hosting (RAX) dropped 12% in early trade after a 70% jump in earnings, to 17 cents, was a penny short of expectations. The company reported late Monday its first-quarter revenue rose 31% to $301 million, better than expected, despite increasing competition among cloud computing capacity providers.The stock had been fighting to hold support at its 10-week moving average since the second week of April.Discovery Communications (DISCA) dropped 5% after first-quarter earnings of 57 cents a share missed views. A 16% gain in revenue, to $1.1 billion, topped expectations.The stock has pulled back to its 10-week moving average.MercadoLibre (MELI) and enterprise software maker Tangoe (TNGO) are reporting results after the close.

Priceline (PCLN) tops the list of IBD 50 companies that are set to report earnings this week as investors look for some good news to rebound from disappointing economic data earlier.The other companies on deck include TransDigm (TDG), Discovery Communications (DISCA) and Fossil (FOSL). The IBD 50 is a list of top growth stocks with top fundamentals and strong relative price strength.TransDigm, an aircraft parts maker, reports Tuesday and has posted accelerating earnings growth for three straight quarters, with gains climbing from 24% to 38%, 42% and 65%.Analysts expect Q2 profit of $1.46 a share, up 50.5% from a year ago. Aerospace suppliers have benefited from growing demand for passenger aircraft, especially in emerging markets.Discovery Communications also reports Tuesday and has notched four consecutive quarters of accelerating profit growth, helped by a lineup of programming with broad appeal across markets.The top provider of "edu-tainment" content, including Animal Planet and Discovery Channel, is expected to earn 60 cents a share in Q2, a 22% increase from a year ago.Fossil is due on Tuesday as well, and analysts see the watchmaker reporting a Q1 profit of 92 cents a share, up 7%. The company has been helped by the renewed popularity of a fashion accessory that was feared would sink into obsolescence with the rise of mobile phones.It also licenses and markets models from Armani, Michael Kors (KORS), DKNY, Burberry and Adidas, and wealthier consumers in Asia have been eager to show off such brands.Priceline will report Wednesday, and expectations are high for another solid quarter of double-digit earnings and revenue growth. Analysts see profit jumping 48% to $3.94 a share.Last quarter, the online travel agency easily topped forecasts on global hotel bookings, especially in Asia and other new markets, which have made up for weakness in Europe.Late last month, rival Expedia (EXPE) reported better-than-expected quarterly results. Last week, Expedia spinoff TripAdvisor (TRIP), an ad-supported user reviews site, also trounced analyst forecasts.

A stronger dollar will rear its head when companies report fourth-quarter earnings, with Apple (AAPL), Google and IBM among those that will be affected.

The rally in the dollar has been driven by the strength of the U.S. economy and expectations for rising interest rates. The big question, though, is how currency weakness in Europe and Japan will factor into Q1 and 2015 guidance on earnings calls, analysts say.

"The decline in the euro, (British) pound and yen is accelerating and is a risk for many companies in Q4 and 2015," said Pacific Crest Securities in a research report late Sunday. "Companies with the most exposure are Priceline (PCLN), Gentex (GNTX), Google (GOOGL) and Harman (HAR) (International)."
Other companies with somewhat less exposure to Europe and Japan include eBay, Amazon.com (AMZN), Facebook (FB) and Discovery (DISCA).
According to Pacific Crest, Chinese Internet companies, including Alibaba (BABA), have "essentially zero" currency risk.
The Q4 and 2015 impact of currency fluctuations on Apple, while exposed to Europe, could be mitigated by growing sales in China, says UBS in a research report.

Barclays, in a report in September, warned that a stronger dollar and weaker euro and yen would spell trouble for many U.S. information technology companies. The companies it identified included IBM (IBM), EMC (EMC), Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) and Juniper Networks (JNPR).
Cisco Systems (CSCO), F5 Networks (FFIV) and Aruba Networks (ARUN) generate 20%-30% of revenue from Europe/Middle East region, but the majority of their sales are denominated in dollars.
Piper Jaffray, in a report Wednesday, said Akamai Technologies' (AKAM) Q4 earnings will be affected by currency.

"Currency will likely prove to be a (revenue drag), likely leading to Q4 results that are only in line with our and street estimates. Thirty percent of Akamai revenue is international (primarily Europe and Japan); both the euro and the yen have depreciated around 5% since the company provided Q4 guidance," wrote Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson.

At Evercore Partners, analyst Jonathan Schildkraut cautions that data center operators such as Digital Realty Trust (DLR) and Equinix (EQIX) as well as Rackspace Hosting (RAX) will be affected by currency fluctuations.
RELATED:
